title: Ken Brown (filmmaker)
text:
Ken Brown (born March 12, 1944, <a href="Dayton%2C%20Ohio">Dayton, Ohio</a>) is an American filmmaker, photographer, <a href="cartoonist">cartoonist</a>, and designer. He grew up in <a href="Amherst%2C%20Massachusetts">Amherst, Massachusetts</a>, relocated to <a href="Cambridge%2C%20Massachusetts">Cambridge, Massachusetts</a>, and currently lives in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. He has directed dozens of animations, experimental films and video documentaries over the last four decades.
Films.
In 1967-69 Brown used <a href="Super%208%20mm%20film">Super 8mm</a> to create psychedelic imagery for the light shows at the Boston Tea Party club. His animated films have been seen on <a href="AMC%20%28TV%20network%29">AMC</a>, <a href="MTV">MTV</a>, <a href="VH1">VH1</a> and "<a href="Sesame%20Street">Sesame Street</a>". A 40-year retrospective of his work was shown January 2007 at the <a href="Anthology%20Film%20Archives">Anthology Film Archives</a>, which outlined Brown's extensive work in the following notes:
Art and ephemera.
His artwork has been exhibited in New York, <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Dallas">Dallas</a>, <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>, <a href="Zurich">Zurich</a> and <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>. He often works in <a href="collage">collage</a>, and many of his images lean toward <a href="surrealism">surrealism</a>. Much of his output has been marketed on postcards, T-shirts, rubberstamps, wrapping paper, mouse pads and kitchen towels. Fine art prints have been made from his extensive collection of vintage postcards and paper ephemera.
Goofy Garden Golf.
In 2004, he teamed with urban installation artist <a href="Maria%20Reidelbach">Maria Reidelbach</a> to create <a href="http%3A//www.hoopla.org/Minigolf/GGGIndex.html">Goofy Garden Golf</a>, a decorative miniature golf course at Pier 25 in Manhattan's Hudson River Park. The Goofy Garden featured the world's largest garden gnome, planned as a tribute to Frieda Carter, who designed the first miniature golf course at <a href="Lookout%20Mountain%2C%20Tennessee">Lookout Mountain, Tennessee</a>, in 1928.
